Situation A. Predicting Shapes Making One Cut

Some interesting shapes result when you cut prisms from different angles. Suppose you start with a rectangular prism like those shown below and make one cut in the directions indicated by the dashed lines. Answer the following questions for each prism.

  1. What are the shapes of the two resulting figures?
  2. What are the shapes of the faces of the figures?
  3. How many vertices, edges, and faces does each figure have?

Rectangle Prism 1:

The indicated horizontal cut will form two rectangular prisms.

Each will have 8 vertices, 12 edges, and 6 rectangular faces.

Rectangle Prism 2:

The indicated slat cut will form two trapezoidal prisms. That is, the base of each will be a trapezoid and the other faces rectangles.

Each part will have 8 vertices, 12 edges, and 6 faces.

(Note: In the image in the Student Edition, the bases are in the position we customarily expect for sides.)

Rectangle Prism 3:

The indicated vertical cut will form two trapezoidal prisms. That is, the top and bottom of each will be a trapezoid and the other faces rectangles.

Each part will have 8 vertices, 12 edges, and 6 faces.

(Note: This cut is really the same as the Rectangle Prism 2, but the starting figure is in a somewhat different position.)

Situation B. Slicing Pyramids

A pyramid is a solid figure with a polygonal base and triangular faces that rise to a common vertex. There are many famous pyramids, such as the ancient great pyramids of Egypt. Some modern buildings are also shaped like pyramids.
1. How could you make cuts into a cube to produce a square pyramid with one side of the cube as its base? Sketch your ideas.

Perhaps the simplest way to cut the cube to make a pyramid would be to pick a point at the center of the square top of the cube and make cuts that go through that point and slant down and outward to the bottom edges of the cube.

Note: Students may need to re-shape their clay from the Initial Challenge back into a cube and experiment with cuts.
2. How could you make cuts into a cube to produce a triangular pyramidâ€”a pyramid that has triangles for all four sides? Sketch your ideas.

Perhaps the simplest cutting strategy to describe for making a triangular pyramid is one with cuts from one vertex on the top of the cube and a diagonal of the base for that cube (not the one that has a vertex just below the point used for the top of the pyramid). There are many other cutting strategies that will work.
3. Suppose you start with a square pyramid and make one slice. Predict the shape of the two solids that result from the cut. Confirm your conjecture by cutting such a pyramid.

There are many possible answers. If a cut is made parallel to the base, another square pyramid and truncated pyramid will result. If a cut is made perpendicular through the vertex to the base, two congruent rectangular pyramids will result. The bases are half the base of the original pyramid.
